awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation on R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 168’ general purpose research vessel owned and operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the United States Academic Research Fleet (ARF).  BIOS is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for-profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the Island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research throughout the Central Atlantic but specifically work in support of the Bermuda Atlantic Time-series (BATS) program. 

With this proposal, BIOS provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Instrumentation:
1)	CTD Carousel Water Sampling Frame		$24,365
2)	Seapoint Fluorometer Migration	$22,934
3)	3.5kHz Transducers	$14,600
	IDC	$10,894
							$72,793

Broader Impacts								
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to acquire and install the following instruments on the R/V Atlantic Explorer. This includes the following: (1) 3.5kHz transducers; (2) CTD Water Sampler Frame; and, (3) Fluorometers.

(1) 3.5kHz transducers: The goal of the 3.5kHz repairs was to restore full performance of our low frequency echosounder which is used for seafloor mapping and sub-bottom profiling. This part of the project will be completed during our current shipyard period which is due to end in February 2025, and will add to the capabilities of the ship to undertake a wider range of scientific cruises.

(2) CTD Water Sampler Frame: We had major corrosion issues on our old CTD rosette due to Seabird's poor design involving the use of multiple mixed metals. We used this information to design and fabricate our own custom frame for the RV Atlantic Explorer. The fabrication of the CTD frame allows the ship to sample the ocean from surface to the deep ocean and recovery a large variety of physical, chemical and biological samples for projects that are aimed at improving the scientific understandig of how the ocean functions, from surface to deep.

(3) Fluorometers: With Seabird Electronics discontinuing support for our Wetstar Fluorometers, we had to find an alternative. After evaluating options on the market, we chose to trial fluorometers manufactured by Seapoint. These fluorometers can be integrated with our CTD and underway seawater sampling system. These sensors also contribute to the ability of the ship to sample the ocean, and in particular, assess the growth rates and amount of marine plants (i.e., phytoplankton) present in waters of different types (surface to deeper) and locations.
